user_message:
Target function code is:
```c
static void
MHD_ip_count_lock (struct MHD_Daemon *daemon)
{
  mhd_assert (NULL == daemon->master);
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ (&daemon->per_ip_connection_mutex);
#else
  (void) daemon;
#endif
}
```

Language extensions should not be used. You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.

Explain why each symbol is required in the analysis of the target function for the MISRA C rule.
close_symbols: struct MHD_Daemon (definition including per_ip_connection_mutex and master)
explanation:
- mhd_assert: The function calls mhd_assert(NULL == daemon->master). mhd_assert may be a macro that expands to compiler-specific builtins or extension constructs (for example __builtin_unreachable). To detect language extensions you must inspect its definition.
- MHD_mutex_lock_chk_: Called when thread support is enabled. This may be a macro or wrapper that itself uses compiler extensions or attributes; its definition is needed to determine if an extension is used.
- struct MHD_Daemon (definition including per_ip_connection_mutex and master): The types of members (per_ip_connection_mutex in particular) may be macros or typedefs that expand to platform-specific constructs (e.g. pthread types, Windows HANDLEs, inline assembly or attributes). Inspecting the struct is necessary to see any extension usage.
- MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS and MHD_USE_W32_THREADS: These compile-time macros control which branch of code is compiled. To determine whether an extension is actually used in a given build/configuration you must know their definitions/values.
- __builtin_unreachable: The static call graph shows this builtin as a callee (likely via mhd_assert). __builtin_unreachable is a compiler/implementation extension; include it to confirm whether it is emitted/used by the code paths and thus violates the MISRA restriction on language extensions.
